After a month of swapping models back and forth, I settled on a daily setup that balances performance √ó price √ó speed. The goal is simple: practical, reusable, and cost‚Äëcontrolled. Here‚Äôs the exact stack and workflows I use daily ‚Äî and recommend to teams and family.

üöÄ 1) Work code: Claude Code 200u (heavy‚Äëduty development)

Section titled ‚ÄúüöÄ 1) Work code: Claude Code 200u (heavy‚Äëduty development)‚Äù

Highlights

  • Run Claude directly in the terminal for transparent, controllable development; Pro/Max subscriptions connect web/desktop/mobile and the CLI.
  • With Opus 4 / Sonnet 4, it sustains long‚Äëchain tasks and complex projects with strong iterative coding ability.
  • Anthropic notes subscription perks like more usage, daily‚Äëtool connections, and extended reasoning ‚Äî a good fit for engineering workflows.

Practical notes

  • Some vendors have introduced weekly throttling/anti‚Äëabuse rules. For heavy use, stage long‚Äërunning tasks and save snapshots to avoid disruption.

Best for

  • Multi‚Äëtask monorepos, cross‚Äëservice refactors, and generate‚Äëdebug‚Äëregress cycles.

Section titled ‚Äúüë™ 7) Family everyday: ChatGPT Plus ($20; Memory is the moat)‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äúüß∞ Quick‚Äëuse checklist‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú‚úÖ Conclusion‚Äù

A good AI stack should swap ‚Äútime anxiety‚Äù for ‚Äústeady delivery.‚Äù This setup is what my team and I actually use. Trim it to your needs; start with one end‚Äëto‚Äëend workflow, then expand.

item.title: The 10√ó Designer Playbook in the AI Era: Curate, Write Clearly, Ship Fast, Tell Stories
item.content:encoded:
For anyone building with AI: upgrade from ‚Äúdrawing screens‚Äù to ‚Äúdesigning systems.‚Äù From ‚ÄúI can produce‚Äù to ‚ÄúI can judge.‚Äù Trade single‚Äëpoint skills for a compound skillset.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Recently, Lovable designer Felix Haas published the ‚ÄúNew Designer Playbook‚Äù: a way to reach 10√ó output in the AI wave. The core is not ‚Äúhow many models you can use,‚Äù but how you judge, express, and turn ideas into shippable products.

This handbook blends Felix‚Äôs public notes with Lovable‚Äôs official practices, adapted into a growth path any product role can execute.

Speed‚Äëread (for the busy)

Section titled ‚ÄúSpeed‚Äëread (for the busy)‚Äù
  • Curate > Create: AI can generate 100 options; your value is which to pick, why, and how to polish.
  • Words are leverage: clear goals, constraints, and acceptance criteria set the ceiling of AI output.
  • Systems > Screens: design journeys, data flows, permissions, and state machines together.
  • Ship to learn: small steps, ship fast, validate while going.
  • Know a bit of tech: APIs, DBs, auth, hosting ‚Äî at least stitch a runnable product.
  • Work with AI: not competing, but using AI to amplify taste and judgment.
  • Tell stories: tie problem, human value, and evidence; stickier products (see method below).

1. Curatorial sense: from ‚Äúcan make‚Äù to ‚Äúcan choose‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú1. Curatorial sense: from ‚Äúcan make‚Äù to ‚Äúcan choose‚Äù‚Äù

Image/text/UI generation is easy; judgment is hard. Build your own ‚Äútaste rules + anti‚Äëpatterns‚Äù:

  • Create a pattern library: components, whitespace, hierarchy, motion you admire.
  • Create an anti‚Äëpattern library: bad palettes, noisy info, anti‚Äëhuman flows.
  • Use the three questions in review: Is it clearer? More credible? More actionable? Curatorial design helps you consistently choose right among AI‚Äôs abundance.

2. Writing: make AI truly understand you

Section titled ‚Äú2. Writing: make AI truly understand you‚Äù

Clarity ships faster. Recast prompts into Goal ‚Äì Constraints ‚Äì Process ‚Äì Acceptance:

  • Goal: for whom, to complete what, faster/with less friction.
  • Constraints: brand tone, palette, component library, compatibility, budget.
  • Process: user flow first, then information architecture, then screens.
  • Acceptance: success metrics, A/B KPIs, usability tasks. Lovable‚Äôs ‚ÄúPrompting Handbook‚Äù formalizes such structured prompts for stable output.

3. Systems thinking: design ‚Äúrunnable products,‚Äù not pages

Section titled ‚Äú3. Systems thinking: design ‚Äúrunnable products,‚Äù not pages‚Äù

Plan journeys, states, permissions, data flow, errors & recovery in one pass; screens are the expression layer.

  • Start with an event flow: trigger ‚Üí validate ‚Üí write/rollback ‚Üí notify.
  • Define a state machine: draft, pending, failed, success, archived.
  • Unify design tokens and voice so teams don‚Äôt drift. Lovable‚Äôs ‚ÄúBest Practices / From idea to app‚Äù breaks ‚Äúconcept ‚Üí runnable‚Äù into repeatable moves.

4. Speed: learning via shipping

Section titled ‚Äú4. Speed: learning via shipping‚Äù

Delivery speed = learning speed.

  • Slice work into 24‚Äëhour shippable increments: solve one narrow problem.
  • Use fake data + real flows first; wire in the real backend when metrics justify.
  • Weekly retro + hygiene: delete dead weight, codify what worked. In PM practice, Lovable stresses: AI lowers implementation barriers ‚Äî strategy and validation become the core.

5. Tech fluency: don‚Äôt be an engineer, but do assemble

Section titled ‚Äú5. Tech fluency: don‚Äôt be an engineer, but do assemble‚Äù

For non‚Äëdevs, master this minimum viable tech list:

  • APIs: read Swagger, call REST/GraphQL.
  • Databases: schema, PK/FK, basic indexes.
  • Auth & access: login, roles, rate limits.
  • Hosting: deploy, logs, rollback. Lovable‚Äôs guides take you step‚Äëby‚Äëstep from first command to full‚Äëstack runnable.

6. Storytelling: make the product more human

Section titled ‚Äú6. Storytelling: make the product more human‚Äù

Frame it as a three‚Äëact story:

  • Character: who is struggling?
  • Conflict: why is the current way painful?
  • Transformation: with your product, what becomes lighter? Close with evidence: metrics, quotes, comparative demos. That ‚Äúhuman flavor‚Äù turns features into a brand. (Felix frequently stresses ‚Äúco‚Äëcreating with AI to amplify humanity and taste.‚Äù)

7. Work with AI: become the ‚Äúchief designer‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú7. Work with AI: become the ‚Äúchief designer‚Äù‚Äù
  • Use AI for rough work: options generation, style fillers, usability sweeps.
  • Keep judgment: you own direction, constraints, acceptance.
  • Teach AI you: encode your style and taboos into templates and system prompts. As Felix puts it: ‚ÄúThe best don‚Äôt compete with AI; they work alongside it.‚Äù

7‚Äëday practice plan (copyable)

Section titled ‚Äú7‚Äëday practice plan (copyable)‚Äù

Day 1: write a Goal‚ÄìConstraints‚ÄìAcceptance prompt template and try your go‚Äëto models. Day 2: build 20 good/bad examples with one‚Äëline rationales. Day 3: upgrade a page into a system diagram (journey/state/permission/data). Day 4: ship a runnable slice on Lovable. Record perf/usability. Day 5: write a 300‚Äëword three‚Äëact product story with two evidence points. Day 6: align API contracts with engineering; add error codes and rollback plans. Day 7: ship + retro: delete one ineffective element; codify one rule that worked.

Tooling (official resources)

Section titled ‚ÄúTooling (official resources)‚Äù
  • Lovable platform & docs: from Figma import to full‚Äëstack shipping.
  • Best Practices / Tips & Tricks: avoid common pitfalls and build team norms.
  • Prompting Handbook: structured prompting, automation, and debugging.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

AI lets anyone ‚Äúproduce,‚Äù but judgment, expression, and making it real are scarce. With curation, writing, systems, speed, technical basics, and storytelling, you‚Äôre no longer ‚Äúsomeone who draws,‚Äù but someone who, with AI, lands value.

Which item would you upgrade first this week?

item.title: Build a Financial Report Auditor Agent with LandingAI ‚Äî Fetch, Extract, Cross‚ÄëCheck, End‚Äëto‚ÄëEnd Automation
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Earnings season brings thick reports, shifting definitions, and inconsistent units. Manual copy‚Äëand‚Äëpaste is tedious and error‚Äëprone.

Here‚Äôs a practical blueprint to automate it with an ‚Äúauditor agent‚Äù: locate the PDF ‚Üí extract key metrics ‚Üí compute ratios ‚Üí cross‚Äëcheck with SEC XBRL APIs ‚Üí output conclusions with an evidence trail. Inspired by LandingAI‚Äôs ADE (Agentic Document Extraction) and the Apple earnings example.

What you‚Äôll get

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôll get‚Äù
  • A reusable technical blueprint (discover ‚Üí extract ‚Üí verify ‚Üí attest).
  • A minimal working code path (Python/Pydantic + ADE + SEC API).
  • Risk & compliance modules (rate limits, User‚ÄëAgent, evidence traceability).

Architecture overview (two paths, cross‚Äëvalidation)

Section titled ‚ÄúArchitecture overview (two paths, cross‚Äëvalidation)‚Äù

Path A | PDF intelligent extraction Investor/Newsroom page ‚Üí find the ‚ÄúConsolidated Financial Statements‚Äù PDF ‚Üí use ADE to extract fields (revenue, net income, diluted EPS) and keep layout coordinates as evidence.

Path B | SEC XBRL structured APIs Call EDGAR XBRL APIs for matching concepts (e.g., us‚Äëgaap: Revenues, NetIncomeLoss, EarningsPerShareDiluted) for secondary verification.

Decisions rely on ‚Äútwo‚Äëway consistency + evidence visualization.‚Äù Any mismatch goes to a human review queue.

Modules and hands‚Äëon

Section titled ‚ÄúModules and hands‚Äëon‚Äù

1) Document discoverer: find the PDF

Section titled ‚Äú1) Document discoverer: find the PDF‚Äù
  • Visit the company‚Äôs Newsroom/IR; e.g., Apple FY2025 Q1 press page has a ‚ÄúView PDF‚Äù link.
  • Use requests + BeautifulSoup to locate the PDF URL; always set a User‚ÄëAgent and follow SEC‚Äôs ‚Äúfair access‚Äù guidance.

Notes

  • For SEC: ‚â§10 req/s and a clear User‚ÄëAgent (company + email) or you‚Äôll be throttled.
  • For Apple and similar IR sites: follow the ‚ÄúView PDF‚Äù link (e.g., FY25_Q1_Consolidated_Financial_Statements.pdf).

2) Document parser: ADE extraction + evidence coordinates

Section titled ‚Äú2) Document parser: ADE extraction + evidence coordinates‚Äù

LandingAI‚Äôs ADE supports pagination for long docs, retries, block‚Äëlevel coordinates, and visual snippets ‚Äî perfect for ‚Äútables + paragraphs‚Äù in financial PDFs. Define desired fields with Pydantic; parse() returns a filled model and bounding boxes for traceability.

Why ‚Äúcoords + snapshots‚Äù? For auditability, review, and replay. If a weird table or a footnote changes the basis, you can jump to the exact page.

3) Metrics calculator: make numbers meaningful

Section titled ‚Äú3) Metrics calculator: make numbers meaningful‚Äù

With revenue/net_income/EPS, do three things first:

  • Profit margin = net income / revenue
  • QoQ/YoY: compare to prior quarter and prior year
  • Threshold alerts: flag outliers (e.g., beyond ¬±3œÉ) or sudden jumps

4) Cross‚Äëchecker: SEC XBRL parity

Section titled ‚Äú4) Cross‚Äëchecker: SEC XBRL parity‚Äù

Use data.sec.gov XBRL APIs for companyfacts or companyconcept: CIK (Apple: 0000320193) ‚Üí us-gaap/NetIncomeLoss, us-gaap/Revenues, us-gaap/EarningsPerShareDiluted. Compare basis, units, and periods; mismatches go to human review.

The SEC provides official XBRL JSON endpoints and asks clients to respect ‚â§10 req/s and custom User‚ÄëAgent.

5) Trustworthiness & risk controls

Section titled ‚Äú5) Trustworthiness & risk controls‚Äù
  • Units and abbreviations: unify millions/thousands/per‚Äëshare; map XBRL units (USD, USD/shares).
  • Negatives and parentheses: parentheses often indicate negatives; normalize to signed numbers.
  • Period selection: Q1/Q2 vs FY ‚Äî ensure date ranges match.
  • Caching & trace: store extraction snapshots, source URLs, timestamps, and content hashes.
  • Polite crawling: throttle for SEC, set a UA with company+email; queue retries when needed.

6) End‚Äëto‚Äëend example (Apple FY2025 Q1)

Section titled ‚Äú6) End‚Äëto‚Äëend example (Apple FY2025 Q1)‚Äù

Apple‚Äôs FY2025 Q1 press release includes a consolidated financial statements PDF; you can run the discoverer ‚Üí parser ‚Üí cross‚Äëchecker chain end to end.

The PDF includes cash flow, income statement, and balance sheet tables, suitable for direct extraction and verification.

7) Deployment shapes and cost tips

Section titled ‚Äú7) Deployment shapes and cost tips‚Äù
  • PoC: Jupyter + SQLite, manual trigger.
  • Small‚Äëscale prod: FastAPI service + Celery/Arq workers, Redis rate limiting, S3 evidence.
  • Notifications: WeCom/Slack message ‚ÄúYoY +X%, margin Y%, evidence link‚Äù.
  • Multi‚Äëcompany sweeps: CIK list + sharded jobs, run overnight.

ADE is a paid API; XBRL endpoints are free but rate‚Äëlimited. Extract from PDF, verify with XBRL for control and cost.

Minimal checklist

Section titled ‚ÄúMinimal checklist‚Äù
  • Page discovery: BeautifulSoup/selector stability ‚Üí fallbacks (keywords + fuzzy matching).
  • Extraction model: Pydantic fields + ADE extraction_model.
  • Verification APIs: companyfacts/companyconcept/frames.
  • Risk & compliance: User‚ÄëAgent, ‚â§10 req/s, evidence retention.

Common extensions

Section titled ‚ÄúCommon extensions‚Äù
  • More fields: operating cash flow, R&D, gross margin, segment revenue.
  • More formats: PDF + iXBRL HTML (directly via SEC XBRL).
  • QC rules: constrain same‚Äëbasis 3‚Äëperiod volatility; flag footnote changes.
  • Explainability: montage extraction snapshots linking back to source pages.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

One person + one machine can run a ‚Äúmini audit desk.‚Äù Find, extract, verify, and explain.

Let agents handle repetition; keep the judgment and insight for yourself.

item.title: Adapt Team Management to the AI Era: Turn Personal ‚ÄòAmplifiers‚Äô into Team Defaults
item.content:encoded:
AI is a personal amplifier. First, use AI to make one ‚Äúlead operator‚Äù self‚Äësustaining; don‚Äôt worship big‚Äëtech resumes; be careful with KPI/OKR idolatry; practice self‚Äëdiscipline to enable others; and remember there is no shortcut. This piece turns those principles into executable team practices.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

AI isn‚Äôt just another tool ‚Äî it multiplies individual firepower. Those who wield it can be ‚Äú1 person doing the work of 10‚Äù; those who don‚Äôt may not even notice the gap widening. Empirical studies show significant productivity gains in writing tasks, and customer support improves by ~14% on average, with larger gains for less experienced workers.

Implication: shift management focus from ‚Äúpolicing process and headcount‚Äù to ‚Äúmanaging leverage and cadence.‚Äù

Eight hard rules to change now

Section titled ‚ÄúEight hard rules to change now‚Äù

1) Make the ‚ÄúAI amplifier‚Äù a default setting

Section titled ‚Äú1) Make the ‚ÄúAI amplifier‚Äù a default setting‚Äù

Set a clear goal: 90% of routine actions have an AI variant. From SOPs, dailies, weekly notes to code reviews and requirement breakdowns ‚Äî always provide a with‚ÄëAI path. Reason: McKinsey estimates $2.6‚Äì$4.4T of annual value from gen‚ÄëAI, compounding labor productivity over time.

2) Build an ‚ÄúAI lead goose,‚Äù then replicate

Section titled ‚Äú2) Build an ‚ÄúAI lead goose,‚Äù then replicate‚Äù

Don‚Äôt train everyone first. Start with 1‚Äì3 lead operators who can run a business slice on AI:

  • A growth thread: lead cleaning, DM automation, landing‚Äëpage A/B.
  • A delivery thread: code+tests generation, doc automation, customer reply drafts. Scale by ‚Äúdemonstrate ‚Üí follow‚Äù to the second wave. Real projects align expectations and shape culture.

3) Evolve performance from ‚Äúoutput volume‚Äù to ‚ÄúAI leverage‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú3) Evolve performance from ‚Äúoutput volume‚Äù to ‚ÄúAI leverage‚Äù‚Äù

Track three dimensions:

  • Efficiency: cycle‚Äëtime reduction for equivalent tasks with‚ÄëAI.
  • Quality: defect rate/CSAT changes attributable to AI (studies show gains in satisfaction and retention).
  • Reuse: number of reusable prompts, workflows, and templates. Don‚Äôt worship KPI/OKR dashboards. HBR warns metrics divorced from strategy backfire; a common OKR mistake is treating tasks as outcomes.

4) Pragmatic hiring: prioritize ‚ÄúAI‚Äëtransferable ability,‚Äù not logos

Section titled ‚Äú4) Pragmatic hiring: prioritize ‚ÄúAI‚Äëtransferable ability,‚Äù not logos‚Äù

Look for:

  • Translating business problems ‚Üí data/tools ‚Üí executable prompts;
  • Productizing personal workflows (scripts, macros, agents);
  • Ability to teach others (clear SOPs/templates);
  • Basic respect for security/compliance (data classification, red‚Äëline awareness).

5) Structure: ‚Äúsmall squads + toolchains,‚Äù learn by shipping

Section titled ‚Äú5) Structure: ‚Äúsmall squads + toolchains,‚Äù learn by shipping‚Äù

Avoid early over‚Äëhiring. Use 4‚Äì6‚Äëperson squads (PM/eng/data/ops) bound to the same prompt library, KB, and automation scripts. Keep human‚ÄìAI collaboration as assets ‚Äî not screenshots of chats.

6) Process shift: from weekly/monthly reports to replayable workflows and real‚Äëtime metrics

Section titled ‚Äú6) Process shift: from weekly/monthly reports to replayable workflows and real‚Äëtime metrics‚Äù

Reports aren‚Äôt the goal; reproducibility is.

  • Record canonical workflows as agent run + prompts + sample data;
  • Dashboard AI calls per capita, hours saved, reuse rate. As process reproducibility increases, outcomes follow; fixation on outcomes alone often reduces effectiveness. (Industry and research agree: deeper AI integration lifts both value and adoption.)

7) Cultural core: self‚Äëdiscipline to enable others ‚Äî turn anxiety into practice

Section titled ‚Äú7) Cultural core: self‚Äëdiscipline to enable others ‚Äî turn anxiety into practice‚Äù

AI isn‚Äôt a replacement machine; it‚Äôs human augmentation. Stanford‚Äôs takeaway: replace humans with AI and you lose; augment humans with AI and you win. Manager moves:

  • Give ‚Äúerror budgets‚Äù and ‚Äúlearning budgets.‚Äù
  • Default to pair‚Äëprompting so newcomers shorten ramp‚Äëup (evidence shows bigger gains for juniors).

8) Don‚Äôt bet on shortcuts; bet on compounding

Section titled ‚Äú8) Don‚Äôt bet on shortcuts; bet on compounding‚Äù

No magic curves, only compounding curves:

  • Ship one reusable workflow every week;
  • Monthly retro on ‚Äúhours saved and quality held‚Äù;
  • Quarterly cleanup of tech‚Äë and data‚Äëdebt. AI adoption is like fitness ‚Äî consistency compounds. Global data shows rapid enterprise adoption; failure to keep pace is falling behind.

Playbook: six 0‚Üí1 transformations

Section titled ‚ÄúPlaybook: six 0‚Üí1 transformations‚Äù

A. People: three‚Äëlayer capability model

Section titled ‚ÄúA. People: three‚Äëlayer capability model‚Äù
  • Base: AI basics (retrieval, rewriting, structuring, review).
  • Middle: task‚Äëchain orchestration (multi‚Äëturn prompts, tool use, RAG/KB).
  • Top: business agentization (auto‚Äëpull data, auto‚Äëgenerate/execute, auto‚Äëretro). Assessment: from ‚Äúcan use‚Äù to ‚Äúcan teach.‚Äù Promotions reward how many others you uplift.

B. Work: ‚Äúlist ‚Üí template ‚Üí automate‚Äù high‚Äëfrequency tasks

Section titled ‚ÄúB. Work: ‚Äúlist ‚Üí template ‚Üí automate‚Äù high‚Äëfrequency tasks‚Äù

Examples:

  • Pre‚Äësales: inquiry classification ‚Üí auto‚Äëreply drafts ‚Üí CRM ingest ‚Üí next‚Äëtouch reminders.
  • Engineering: requirements ‚Üí cases ‚Üí code ‚Üí tests ‚Üí deploy scaffolds.
  • Support: ticket similarity ‚Üí answer drafts ‚Üí second review ‚Üí FAQ back to KB.

C. Tools: a three‚Äëlayer stack

Section titled ‚ÄúC. Tools: a three‚Äëlayer stack‚Äù

item.title: Palantir Shorts vs. AI Hype: Valuation, Risks, and Opportunities
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Palantir Technologies (ticker: PLTR) has surged this year on the ‚Äúartificial intelligence (AI)‚Äù narrative, becoming a market darling. Yet behind the stock‚Äôs multiple expansions, short sellers (e.g., Citron Research) argue its valuation has detached from fundamentals.

As investors, we should examine calmly: What are the core claims from the short side? How has AI euphoria inflated its multiples? What do the latest financials actually imply? What risks come with shorting this stock? Looking ahead, do Palantir‚Äôs government contracts and data platform commercialization provide mid‚Äë to long‚Äëterm upside?

The short case: sky‚Äëhigh valuation and growth concerns

Section titled ‚ÄúThe short case: sky‚Äëhigh valuation and growth concerns‚Äù

1. Extreme multiples

  • Price‚Äëto‚Äësales peaked around 80‚Äì100√ó; forward P/E 200‚Äì300√ó.
  • Citron‚Äôs Andrew Left called Palantir‚Äôs valuation ‚Äúabsurdly‚Äù rich.
  • Even on NVIDIA‚Äëstyle multiples, Palantir could still need a major haircut.
  • Within the S&P 500, Palantir is cited as one of the most expensive names, with forward P/E ~245√ó vs NVIDIA ~35√ó.

2. Business model skepticism

  • OpenAI benefits from a self‚Äëreinforcing user‚Äëgrowth flywheel; Palantir relies largely on customized contracts.
  • Looks like ‚Äúconsulting + packaged software,‚Äù limiting scale efficiency.

3. Results and customer mix

  • Over half of revenue depends on U.S. government contracts.
  • Commercial expansion is slower (roughly 20% growth), falling short of AI‚Äëboom expectations.

4. Insider selling

  • CEO Alex Karp has reportedly sold nearly $2B of stock over two years.
  • Interpreted as wavering confidence and fuels market doubts.

How AI euphoria skews valuation

Section titled ‚ÄúHow AI euphoria skews valuation‚Äù
  • Global AI equities trade around 30√ó forward P/E, well above the S&P 500‚Äôs ~19√ó.
  • Palantir‚Äôs YTD gain exceeded 130% at one point, emblematic of the AI story trade.
  • Investors chase narrative over fundamentals; even Sam Altman has cautioned about bubble signs.

Double‚Äëedged sword:

  • Upside: markets award premium multiples; some dub Palantir the ‚ÄúOracle of AI.‚Äù
  • Risk: when heat fades, multiples can compress quickly.

Latest results and comp table

Section titled ‚ÄúLatest results and comp table‚Äù

Highlights:

  • 2025 Q2 revenue topped $1B for the first time, +48% YoY.
  • U.S. commercial +93% YoY; government +53%.
  • EPS $0.16; operating margin 46.3%; FCF margin 57%.

Valuation comps:

  • Palantir: P/S ~ 80√ó; P/E ~ 200‚Äì300√ó.
  • NVIDIA: P/E ~35√ó.
  • Microsoft/Google: P/E ~30√ó.
  • OpenAI (private): ~$500B valuation, P/S ~17√ó.

üëâ On OpenAI‚Äëstyle multiples, Palantir‚Äôs ‚Äúfair‚Äù price might be around $40, well below spot.

Risks of shorting Palantir

Section titled ‚ÄúRisks of shorting Palantir‚Äù
  • Retail sponsorship: like GameStop, sentiment can squeeze price higher.
  • Low short interest: ~2.5% vs C3.ai‚Äôs ~20%.
  • Headline sensitivity: a big contract or AI milestone can spike shares and squeeze shorts.

Mid‚Äë to long‚Äëterm potential

Section titled ‚ÄúMid‚Äë to long‚Äëterm potential‚Äù

1. Government moat

  • Long relationships with DoD and intelligence agencies; long cycles, large dollars.
  • Latest DoD contract reportedly expanded to $1.3B, running through 2029.

2. Commercial expansion

  • AIP (AI Platform) trials across banking, healthcare, and manufacturing.
  • Q2 added 157 $1M+ contracts ‚Äî clear progress in commercialization.

3. Healthy financial profile

  • High gross margin and strong FCF; multiple profitable quarters.
  • Unlike ‚Äúpure AI concept‚Äù names relying on external financing.

4. Structural tailwinds

  • Rising AI and analytics penetration.
  • Palantir could become the ‚Äúenterprise data operating system.‚Äù
  • Some analysts have lifted targets to $150‚Äì200.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Palantir sits at a controversial crossroads:

  • Bears argue valuation far exceeds fundamentals and will normalize.
  • Bulls point to the government moat and AIP traction, expecting earnings to fill the gap.

Investor takeaway:

  • Beware of bubbles, but don‚Äôt ignore long‚Äëterm potential.
  • Near‚Äëterm volatility is high; both long and short carry risk.
  • Long‚Äërun value will be determined by execution and landing real products.

In the short run, markets are a voting machine; in the long run, a weighing machine. Whether Palantir grows into its valuation will be answered by innovation and results.

item.title: Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot Subscriptions Too Expensive? Maybe It's Time to Learn from TikTok
item.content:encoded:
Claude Code, Cursor, Copilot Subscriptions Too Expensive? Maybe It‚Äôs Time to Learn from TikTok

Section titled ‚ÄúClaude Code, Cursor, Copilot Subscriptions Too Expensive? Maybe It‚Äôs Time to Learn from TikTok‚Äù

How Mainstream AI Programming Assistants Make Money

Section titled ‚ÄúHow Mainstream AI Programming Assistants Make Money‚Äù

Current popular AI programming tools like GitHub Copilot, Cursor, and Claude Code primarily follow subscription-based business models with monthly fees. These tools are also experiencing rapid user growth:

  • GitHub Copilot (Microsoft GitHub): Individual subscription around $10/month, providing code auto-completion and chat features. Since launching in 2021, it has gained massive popularity, with over 20 million users having tried Copilot by 2025 (all-time users). Paid users exceed 1.8 million (as of early 2024). Copilot is also popular in enterprise - Microsoft CEO Nadella revealed that 90% of Fortune 100 companies use Copilot. With subscription pricing, Microsoft also bundles it into more expensive enterprise packages. Leveraging the massive developer ecosystem, Copilot‚Äôs revenue growth is rapid - in 2024, Nadella said its ‚Äúbusiness scale has exceeded the entire GitHub when Microsoft acquired it in 2018.‚Äù

  • Cursor (developed by Anysphere): An AI code editor built on VS Code, using a freemium model. Individuals get free Hobby version (with two-week Pro trial) and paid Pro version ($20/month); power users have $200/month Ultra tier with higher usage limits and priority new features. This pricing is quite affordable, leading to explosive Cursor user growth. Early 2025 reports suggested Cursor daily active users exceeded 1 million, with annualized recurring revenue around $200 million; months later its ARR climbed to $500 million - stunning growth showing many users willing to pay. However, Cursor team faces escalating costs as users grow. Reports indicate many AI programming companies have near-zero or negative gross margins due to high model inference costs, with ‚Äúall code generation products having either zero or negative profit margins.‚Äù Despite Anysphere reaching $500 million ARR by June 2024, becoming one of the fastest SaaS companies to break $100M ARR, high compute costs pressure profits, forcing pricing strategy adjustments to shift some excess usage costs to heavy users.

  • Claude Code (launched by Anthropic): Anthropic integrates its advanced Claude model into terminals and IDEs, creating this AI programming assistant. Claude Code doesn‚Äôt charge separately but is included in Claude.ai subscription plans: individual Pro plan $20/month (about $17/month annually), subscription includes Claude Code access. Higher-tier Max plans at $100/month (5x usage) or $200/month (20x usage) provide larger context windows and stronger models (Claude Opus 4.1). In other words, Claude Code follows a ‚Äúsubscribe for AI service, get tools included‚Äù approach, using valuable coding assistants to attract developers to subscribe to AI services. Anthropic also offers usage-based API pricing for enterprises. Claude Code emphasizes deep code understanding and cross-file editing, receiving good feedback from professional development teams. However, compared to Copilot and Cursor, Claude Code user scale data is less public, possibly because it mainly targets paid user groups, using refined operations rather than broad-net strategies.

Overall, these AI programming assistants primarily use subscription monetization, ranging from tens to hundreds of dollars monthly, targeting the market where programmers pay for efficiency. Free users either cannot access features (Copilot discontinued free trials) or face significant limitations (Cursor free version has usage limits). While this business model is direct, it means no payment equals no full functionality. Could there be alternative approaches using common internet advertising/entertainment monetization methods to create new revenue streams for these AI tools? Before discussing this idea, let‚Äôs examine how short videos, live streaming, gaming and other sectors ‚Äúmake money.‚Äù

Short Videos, Live Streaming, Advertising: Internet‚Äôs Golden Money-Making Playbook

Section titled ‚ÄúShort Videos, Live Streaming, Advertising: Internet‚Äôs Golden Money-Making Playbook‚Äù

In the internet industry, user attention is hard currency. Short video platforms, live streaming, advertising distribution, and mobile games all achieve commercial value by capturing user attention for extended periods:

  • Short Videos (Douyin/TikTok): Through precise algorithmic recommendations, users scroll videos endlessly, enabling interspersed feed advertising for efficient monetization. Taking Douyin as example, by 2024 its monthly active users reached 1 billion (China only). Users spend average 110 minutes daily on Douyin, nearly equivalent to watching a full movie! With long user engagement, ads get ample display opportunities. Douyin‚Äôs advertising revenue soars, projected to reach $30 billion in 2024 (including splash screens, feeds, stickers, etc.). Additionally, Douyin integrates live commerce and e-commerce traffic, expanding monetization scenarios - statistics show over 40% of daily active users watch or participate in Douyin live commerce. Short video platforms dramatically increase user stickiness through algorithms + content, exchanging massive user time for high advertising revenue.

  • Video Websites (YouTube): As traditional long-video platform, YouTube‚Äôs main revenue also comes from ad insertion and creator revenue sharing. YouTube has 2.49 billion monthly active users globally, with 2023 advertising revenue reaching $31 billion. Average users spend nearly 49 minutes daily watching YouTube. The platform profits through pre-roll, mid-roll, and recommended page ads, then shares revenue with content creators. This model validates the logic that ‚Äúas long as users watch long enough, ads will sell.‚Äù Recently YouTube introduced Shorts and live streaming, further increasing user engagement and enriching ad inventory. Video platforms use massive content to retain users, then monetize through advertising - a mature and efficient business logic.

  • Live Streaming Platforms (Twitch, etc.): Live streaming stimulates user enthusiasm through real-time interaction, beyond advertising, also driving user donations and subscriptions. Amazon‚Äôs gaming live streaming platform Twitch achieved 20.8 billion hours of total viewing time in 2024, with about 240 million monthly active users globally and 35 million daily active users. Half of Twitch‚Äôs revenue comes from advertising (ads inserted in streamer broadcasts, platform shares with streamers), half from user subscriptions and gift donations. Twitch generated approximately $1.8 billion revenue in 2024. Though smaller user base than short videos, dedicated viewers willing to pay for favorite streamers means higher ARPU (Average Revenue Per User). Live streaming monetization centers on strong community atmosphere: real-time chat, emotional connections between fans and streamers all increase user payment willingness. This model proves that even without short video-scale mass appeal, strong stickiness and deep interaction can generate considerable revenue.

  • Mobile Games and Interactive Games: Many games, especially free mobile games, monetize through in-app purchases and advertising. On one hand, few paying players (‚Äúwhales‚Äù) contribute purchase revenue, on the other hand, many non-paying players become advertising monetization targets by watching ads for in-game rewards. Some casual mobile games design ‚Äúwatch 30-second ad for coins‚Äù mechanics, or insert ads during level loading. This ‚Äúexchange waiting time for revenue‚Äù approach is common. Statistics show 2024 global mobile gaming market revenue exceeded $111 billion, with advertising revenue comprising significant portion. Google even launched App Open Ads specifically for displaying ads during app loading screens, letting developers monetize user waiting seconds. Gaming industry deeply understands this: monetize fragmented time, not wasting any moment users stay on screen.

In summary, whether short videos or live streaming, the underlying business logic is using excellent content or interactive experiences to keep users on platforms as long as possible, then monetizing user attention through advertising or value-added services. Can this logic transfer to AI programming assistants? Could we envision a model where programmers watch customized short videos or interactive content during AI coding breaks, using entertainment advertising revenue to replace part of subscription fees? This sounds far-fetched, but let‚Äôs boldly brainstorm.

Can You Watch Videos While AI Writes Code? Feasibility Analysis

Section titled ‚ÄúCan You Watch Videos While AI Writes Code? Feasibility Analysis‚Äù

Imagine a typical scenario: programmer Zhang uses AI assistant in VS Code to generate code, sometimes waiting several seconds for model results. These few seconds of downtime currently mean staring at ‚ÄúThinking‚Ä¶‚Äù cursor. What if Zhang could see interesting content during these gaps, utilizing fragmented time?

Technically, this isn‚Äôt impossible. AI programming tools typically exist as plugins or standalone applications - Copilot is IDE plugin, Cursor is VS Code-based standalone editor, Claude Code runs in terminal/IDE. These tool interfaces could easily reserve small windows to push content during AI request processing. Similar to loading tips on web pages or mobile game loading screens, except here it could be personalized video/information feeds.

The key is what content to push that‚Äôs both engaging and non-disruptive to work? Learning from short video and content recommendation experience, ideal approach is precise interest matching. AI assistants already understand user code and context - with user authorization, they might guess user interests based on coding themes. For example:

  • When users write Python code for unit testing, small window pushes ‚Äú3 Tips for Improving Test Efficiency‚Äù short video, 30 seconds perfectly matching current task.
  • During debugging downtime, push programmer humor short videos or funny memes, making users smile and relieving frustration.
  • Based on user preferences (like frequently reading frontend articles), recommend related tech influencer live clips or new product launch segments, keeping users updated on industry trends.

Of course, implementing smart recommendations requires building content recommendation algorithms. Could reference TikTok‚Äôs multi-layer machine learning models, rapidly iterating recommendations based on user behavior. AI programming assistants already call large models to understand code context, could combine with user-set interest tags for content filtering. Let users check preferred content types in settings: ‚ÄúTech tutorials / Tech news / Comedy / Gaming streams / ‚Ä¶‚Äù then assistant selects pushes accordingly.

More importantly, controlling frequency and format. Programmers need focus for coding, can‚Äôt let popup content overshadow main functionality. Ideal design is embedded: editor sidebar shows small muted video window, or output area displays news feed cards. After AI response generation, content auto-collapses without interrupting user flow. Google‚Äôs App Open Ads emphasizes choosing natural timing (like loading screens) for ad display, avoiding core experience disruption. Similarly, AI assistant content pushes should only occur during natural pauses like model computation or code compilation, with one-click close option.

For monetization, these pushed contents could include advertising elements. For example, pushed short videos feature vendor-promoted new developer tools (presented as content marketing), or live streams embed product links (users might need technical books/courses). Bing Chat already experiments with embedding ad links in chat answers, Microsoft states will share ad revenue with content providers. This shows integrating advertising into AI responses/interfaces is viable commercial attempt. In coding assistant scenarios, advertising could be more subtle and relevant: when users use free AI assistant for frontend code, small window recommends ‚Äúmore efficient frontend debugging tool‚Äù (actually advertising partnership promotion), users click if interested or skip if not, experience similar to seeing ads on TikTok.

Any Precedents? Industry Exploration and Comparisons

Section titled ‚ÄúAny Precedents? Industry Exploration and Comparisons‚Äù

This ‚ÄúAI programming + entertainment advertising‚Äù model currently lacks direct mature cases, but related explorations exist:

  • Developer Community Advertising Attempts: Traditional programming Q&A sites like Stack Overflow historically monetized through page ads and enterprise recruitment ads. Though not AI tools, this shows developers aren‚Äôt completely ad-averse, provided ad content is highly relevant and doesn‚Äôt interfere with getting answers. Similarly, if AI assistants push developer-related news or products (like cloud service promotions, tech conference live previews), users might welcome them, even finding them educational.

  • AI Chat and Advertising Integration: Microsoft‚Äôs new Bing (Bing Chat) already inserts sponsored links in GPT-4 powered chat answers, sometimes including product ad cards for shopping queries. This essentially embeds search advertising directly into conversations. Though coding assistant scenarios differ from search, Bing‚Äôs practice proves large model responses and commercial advertising can coexist. Key is transparent labeling and relevance, letting users clearly identify ads while ensuring ads truly match their needs.

  • AI Tool Extension Windows: Some programming tools already show signs of news pushing. For example, JetBrains IDE shows ‚ÄúTip of the Day‚Äù on startup, VS Code welcome page often has recommended articles or update announcements. These are embedded information content within tool interfaces, just not yet commercialized. If these windows became customizable content streams, it would be technically natural.

  • Free Models and User Scale: Currently some AI programming tools take free routes to attract users, then seek other monetization. For example, open-source Codeium is free for individuals, using data to improve models then charging enterprises later. But no clear ‚Äúfree + advertising‚Äù cases exist. On one hand, developer user base is much smaller than consumer apps, whether advertising monetization can cover high compute costs is questionable. On the other hand, programmer users demand higher product purity, rashly adding ads might cause backlash. So most startups choose direct subscription fees or enterprise payment rather than prioritizing advertising models.

  • Domestic Developments: Worth noting, domestic tech giants are also advancing AI coding assistants, like Alibaba‚Äôs ‚ÄúTongyi Lingma.‚Äù According to Alibaba‚Äôs 2025 financial report, Tongyi Lingma (coding assistant) achieved strong revenue growth. However, it mainly targets enterprise customers, representing successful B2B paid model, different from our discussed C2C entertainment advertising approach. Tencent states AI technology has contributed to its performance advertising and gaming businesses, indirectly proving AI and advertising integration potential.

Overall, currently no direct products fusing programming assistants with entertainment content monetization, but from search chat to app loading ads to various successful freemium models, many borrowable elements exist. If some team dares break conventions, launching such ‚Äúcode writing + video watching‚Äù crossover product, it might truly open new blue ocean.

Future Outlook: AI Programming Assistant Entertainment Path

Section titled ‚ÄúFuture Outlook: AI Programming Assistant Entertainment Path‚Äù

Imagine future development scenarios: you sit at computer writing code, AI assistant helps debug. During compilation breaks, it thoughtfully pushes ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs Programming Joke‚Äù short video for entertainment, or pops up AR real-scene hacker mini-game for few seconds of brain relaxation. This might sound absurd, but isn‚Äôt impossible. As new generation developers gradually adapt to multitasking and fragmented information streams, this work-entertainment intertwined mode might be more popular than imagined.

Commercially, ‚ÄúAI programming + entertainment advertising‚Äù model could bring win-win:

  • For individual developers, lower entry barriers - maybe no expensive subscription fees needed, just free access to powerful code AI tools, only tolerating some well-timed content pushes as exchange. Same logic already accepted in mobile apps (many apps offer ‚Äúwatch ads to unlock premium features‚Äù options).

  • For platform vendors, diversified revenue sources, shared compute costs. Current AI programming assistant profitability challenges largely stem from each additional user means additional compute costs, unlike traditional software where expansion doesn‚Äôt increase marginal costs. Introducing advertising monetization means even non-paying users generate revenue through ad viewing, helping subsidize model inference costs, alleviating ‚Äúmore users, more losses‚Äù predicament. This could make business models more sustainable.

  • For advertisers, new channel reaching programmer demographics. Programmers as high-consumption, high-decision-influence group have always been desired but hard-to-reach audience for many B2B and tech product advertisers. If programming scenario native ad placements exist, promoting cloud services, development tools, IT books/courses and other vertical products could have higher conversion rates than random TikTok advertising. Especially combined with AI understanding of user code intent, ad precision would improve significantly (provided privacy permissions and careful balance, otherwise easily causing backlash).

Of course, this path faces considerable challenges. First, not affecting user experience is biggest test. Programmers need long-term focused thinking, frequent entertainment content popups would interrupt flow. If content quality is poor or irrelevant, users would rather close assistant than be disturbed. Therefore content recommendations must be sufficiently personalized and valuable, ideally inspiring work (like recommending related technical solution video tutorials, more acceptable than pure commercial ads). Simultaneously need complete user control, like setting ‚Äúfocus mode‚Äù with no content pushes, or allowing paid ad removal (like many apps‚Äô ‚Äúremove ads pro version‚Äù).

Second, scale effects are problematic. Global developer numbers are large but far from entertainment app user bases. To rely on advertising monetization, per-user ad revenue must cover model inference costs, requiring improvements in both ad effectiveness and compute cost reduction. One possibility is introducing gamification elements to stimulate usage time: like coding challenge mini-games where users playing trains models while exposing more ads, killing multiple birds. But these ideas need practical validation.

Finally, from trends perspective, AI tool entertainment and advertising is indeed an anticipatable direction. Just as adding games to office software sounds ridiculous, but Microsoft Teams already has built-in casual games for colleague meeting breaks, proving traditional productivity tools are experimenting with entertainment elements. Similarly, future AI programming assistants needn‚Äôt be cold tools, could become interesting, cute, even ‚Äúcomedian‚Äù personalities. When post-90s, post-00s become development mainstream, they might prefer work becoming as ‚Äúmeme-filled‚Äù as browsing Weibo. Once user mindsets shift, business model innovation has fertile ground.

Summary and Brainstorming: AI programming assistants moving from paid to free + advertising represents interesting crossover fusion imagination. It represents future possibility: work and entertainment no longer clearly separated, but naturally fused through AI bridges. Maybe in few years, when you use AI to write code, it‚Äôll play programming tutorial live replays when you‚Äôre debugging stuck, let you play pixel-style coder jumping games during project builds. Then coding experience becomes both efficient and fun, coding no longer boring, bugs gain some playful seasoning.

Of course, this remains bold speculation. But these imaginative ideas point toward possible next directions. After all, in AI era world, imagination is often the best productivity. Let‚Äôs wait and see - maybe the next industry-disrupting business model will emerge from such brainstorming.

item.title: Conquering Complexity with Add & Divide: The 80/20 Truth of Generative AI
item.content:encoded:
The big victory of generative AI boils down to two small things: addition and division. Add one more time-honored rule of the game: 80/20.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

We often mystify AI. Crack open a mainstream generative model and its most common moves are downright plain: weighted sums (addition), normalization (division), and residual addition (addition). Attention is a weighted sum; softmax and normalization use division; layer normalization divides by the standard deviation; residual networks add inputs directly to outputs. These ‚Äúbrick-laying‚Äù operations somehow stack into today‚Äôs miracles.

Why does such simplicity work? The answer points to two ideas: low-dimensional manifolds + 80/20. The world looks high-dimensional and chaotic, yet the patterns that actually occur are squeezed onto a few ‚Äúmain roads.‚Äù If you catch that 20% of main roads, you can explain 80% of phenomena.

I. The ‚ÄúAdd/Divide‚Äù Aesthetics of Models

Section titled ‚ÄúI. The ‚ÄúAdd/Divide‚Äù Aesthetics of Models‚Äù

Attention = weighted sum + normalization In Transformers, the attention output is a weighted sum over V; the weights come from softmax(QK^T / ‚àöd_k), which hides a division (scaling). It‚Äôs ‚Äúwho resembles me ‚Üí how much weight ‚Üí add it up.‚Äù

Layer normalization = subtract mean + divide by std LayerNorm computes mean and variance, then divides by the standard deviation to stabilize feature distributions and ease training.

Residual connections = direct addition ResNet‚Äôs ‚Äúshortcut‚Äù adds the input as-is to the output, preserving information and smoothing gradients so very deep networks are trainable.

Diffusion models = a loop of adding noise / removing noise During training we gradually add Gaussian noise; during generation we denoise in reverse. At heart it‚Äôs linear combinations and normalization again.

Naively simple? Yes. But when data lies along a low-dimensional main road, these linear/near-linear ‚Äúadd‚Äìsubtract‚Äìmultiply‚Äìdivide‚Äù moves are enough to sketch that road.

II. Why the World Respects ‚ÄúSimple Methods‚Äù: Low-D Manifolds + 80/20

Section titled ‚ÄúII. Why the World Respects ‚ÄúSimple Methods‚Äù: Low-D Manifolds + 80/20‚Äù

The manifold hypothesis says that although natural data lives in high-dimensional space, effective samples concentrate on a low-dimensional manifold. Many studies find that learned representations in deep nets have intrinsic dimensionality far below the surface dimensionality‚Äîthe model is compressing the world.

Enter 80/20: When the critical structure occupies ‚Äúfew dimensions,‚Äù grabbing the vital 20% of features can reproduce 80% of the phenomena. This isn‚Äôt mysticism; power-law/Pareto patterns are frequent guests in nature and human systems.

There‚Äôs also an industry consensus: neural network scaling laws show that as you scale model, data, and compute, the loss falls along a power law. Simple architectures + large-scale ‚Äúadd‚Äìsubtract‚Äìmultiply‚Äìdivide‚Äù can steadily eat into more complex patterns.

We can visualize this with a metaphor: imagine standing on a vast prairie (a high-dimensional space). In theory you can walk in any direction, but in practice most people travel along a few clear trails. Footsteps aren‚Äôt random; together they stamp out a handful of paths favored by nature. Those trails are the ‚Äúmanifolds of natural preference.‚Äù Weather changes, protein folding, and image generation are similar‚Äîalthough the possibility space is enormous, real situations compress into low-dimensional regions.

III. A Hard-Core Case: How AlphaFold ‚ÄúHarvests the Manifold‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. A Hard-Core Case: How AlphaFold ‚ÄúHarvests the Manifold‚Äù‚Äù

The theoretical conformation space of proteins is absurdly large‚Äîon the order of 10^300‚Äîso brute force is impossible. Yet nature folds proteins in milliseconds, implying the true folding path is compressed onto a low-dimensional main road. AlphaFold learned this road from vast sequence‚Äìstructure pairs, then locates the most likely structure directly in that ‚Äúroad space.‚Äù

The upgraded AlphaFold 3 even folds in a diffusion architecture, using a differentiable ‚Äúadd noise/denoise‚Äù pipeline to jointly predict complexes, ions, and small molecules‚Äîagain, a simple operations assembly line serving low-dimensional structure.

Some liken it to ‚Äúinferring a few plastic leaves and mirrors from a kaleidoscope pattern.‚Äù In plain terms: compress the complex surface into a small set of stable structures.

IV. Operationalizing: Use 80/20 to Thin and Deepen Your Generative Workflow

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Operationalizing: Use 80/20 to Thin and Deepen Your Generative Workflow‚Äù

1) Data side: prioritize ‚Äúmain road‚Äù samples

  • Review 30 days of real tasks and tally the top 20% scenarios/styles by frequency; create high-quality samples and templates for them first.
  • Build your eval set with Pareto coverage: max out the core 80% first, then expand to the long tail. (A Pareto chart makes this vivid.)

2) Prompting side: make ‚Äúadd/divide‚Äù concrete

  • Addition: provide explicit weighted factors (goal, audience, style, length, banned terms). Pair each factor with examples‚Äîthis feeds ‚Äúweights‚Äù to attention.
  • Division: norms and constraints are ‚Äúdivision‚Äù‚Äîlength caps, structure templates, term glossaries, scoring rubrics all scale/normalize the model‚Äôs output.
  • Pattern: a handful of high-quality few-shot examples > a pile of fuzzy cases (they act as anchors to the ‚Äúmain road‚Äù).

3) Retrieval/RAG: put your corpus on a diet

  • Only ingest the top 20% highest-weight documents (authoritative, freshest, widest coverage).
  • Keep each retrieval small and sharp with top-k, and force cite-and-link positions to reduce ‚Äúoff-road‚Äù wandering.

4) Evaluation and launch: two stages

  • Phase A: hammer on reliability across the 80% high-frequency main roads (auto-scoring + light human review).
  • Phase B: tackle the long tail by iterating in order of impact √ó frequency.

V. Don‚Äôt Forget the Boundary Conditions

Section titled ‚ÄúV. Don‚Äôt Forget the Boundary Conditions‚Äù

Simple is strong, not omnipotent.

  • Domain shift/long tail: models learn ‚Äúthis main road.‚Äù Out-of-distribution (OOD) they stumble; you need new data/constraints to pave a new road. Proteins are similar‚Äîcertain classes or disordered regions remain tough.
  • Power laws aren‚Äôt laws of nature: 80/20 is a common empirical pattern; don‚Äôt apply it mechanically.
  • ‚ÄúInformation-first‚Äù ontology is debated: treating physics as information-first is tempting, but credible counter-arguments exist. Don‚Äôt canonize it.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

If you see generative AI as a crew doing addition/division, guided by a low-dimensional road map, many thorny problems suddenly get simpler. Compress first, then orchestrate; first the 20%, then the 80%. That‚Äôs today‚Äôs blunt method‚Äîand the steadiest kind of cleverness.

item.title: AI Prompt Writing Technique: Two-Stepping Method - Generate First, Then Optimize
item.content:encoded:
First, let AI complete the task normally; then in the same prompt, have it immediately summarize, polish, refactor, or self-check the just-produced content. One prompt, double value.

Two-Stepping has been continuously promoted by creator Rob Lennon in public posts and courses, adopted by many content and product teams. Its core is the sequential thinking of ‚Äúgenerate first, optimize later.‚Äù

Why Does the ‚ÄúTwo-Step Method‚Äù Work So Well?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Does the ‚ÄúTwo-Step Method‚Äù Work So Well?‚Äù

1) Reduces cognitive load. Cramming too many requirements at once causes the model to get distracted, pulled in different directions, and conflicted. Breaking it into ‚Äúdo the work first, then review‚Äù is more stable. This approach aligns with academia‚Äôs self-feedback ‚Üí rewrite approach: first produce a draft, then have the model provide feedback and revise accordingly, showing significant improvements across multiple tasks (research reports show improvement ranges of 5%‚Äì40%).

2) Lets the model ‚Äúsee itself‚Äù and then optimize. After the model writes out its thoughts, it has a ‚Äúcriticizable‚Äù object; reviewing based on the finished product often yields higher quality. Similar two-stage processes commonly seen in research: first produce then answer/review, also proven to be more stable.

3) Solves ‚Äúoutput + processing‚Äù in one prompt. Stringing ‚Äúwrite ‚Üí revise ‚Üí compress ‚Üí style conversion‚Äù into the same prompt reduces round trips and maintains context consistency. Rob Lennon‚Äôs Two-Stepping concept and course practice also emphasize breaking complex tasks into executable sequential steps.

Applicable Scenarios (The More ‚ÄúProcessing-Heavy,‚Äù the Better)

Section titled ‚ÄúApplicable Scenarios (The More ‚ÄúProcessing-Heavy,‚Äù the Better)‚Äù
  • Content Creation: Long article ‚Üí 50-word lead / 3 key points / multi-platform adaptation.
  • Product & Documentation: PRD ‚Üí risk checklist / review questions / acceptance criteria.
  • Programming Collaboration: Generate function ‚Üí unit tests + edge cases + self-check report.
  • Data Analysis: Full analysis ‚Üí conclusion table / decision recommendations / retrospective points.
  • Marketing Growth: Ad script ‚Üí objection handling version / A/B copy / platform adaptation.

The underlying logic aligns with ‚ÄúSelf-Refine‚Äù: the generate‚Äîfeedback‚Äîregenerate loop, proven to steadily improve result quality.

Ready-to-Use: 4 ‚ÄúTwo-Step Method‚Äù Super Templates (Copy & Paste)

Section titled ‚ÄúReady-to-Use: 4 ‚ÄúTwo-Step Method‚Äù Super Templates (Copy & Paste)‚Äù

Universal Version (Works for Any Task)

First, complete the task according to the following requirements: ‚Äì Goal: {your desired result} ‚Äì Audience: {who will see it} ‚Äì Constraints: {length/style/forbidden elements} ‚Äì Output format: {structure/fields} Then, based on the content you just output, do secondary processing: ‚Äì Extract 3‚Äì5 key points + 1 golden sentence ‚Äì Point out 3 areas for improvement and provide the complete improved version ‚Äì Provide a ‚Äúshorter, more conversational‚Äù version (‚â§ {word count})

Content Creation Version (Long Article ‚Üí Title Matrix + Social Media Cards)

First write an article about {topic}, including: introduction/3‚Äì5 sections/conclusion/call to action. Then output secondary results:

  1. 10 convertible titles (with emotional words/numbers/promises),
  2. 50-word lead + 3 key points,
  3. Generate 2 social media posts for {platform}.

Programming Version (Function ‚Üí Unit Tests + Self-Check Report)

First implement {function/module}, requirements: readability, exception handling, complete comments. Then: ‚Äì Generate high-coverage unit tests (list edge cases and expected results) ‚Äì Provide complexity assessment and 3 refactoring suggestions, with improved code ‚Äì Output a ‚Äúself-check report‚Äù (defects, risks, improvement points)

Analysis & Decision Version (Insights ‚Üí Decision-Ready)

First complete analysis of {data/solution/competitors}, output structured conclusions. Then provide: ‚Äì Decision overview (TL;DR 100 words) ‚Äì 3 recommendations for leadership with implementation checklist (owner, milestones, metrics) ‚Äì Possible objections and counterargument points

Tip: Treat the ‚Äúthen‚Äù part as ‚Äúeditor/QA role description‚Äù ‚Äì whatever role you‚Äôre playing, the model will improve toward that standard. This approach aligns with ‚Äútwo-stage prompting/self-feedback iteration‚Äù research conclusions.

Real-World Examples (Close to Your Daily Work)

Section titled ‚ÄúReal-World Examples (Close to Your Daily Work)‚Äù

1) WeChat Article Production Pipeline

  • First write 1200‚Äì1500 word main text (with subheadings, bold text).
  • Then produce 50-word lead, 3 key points, ending CTA, 10 title alternatives, one-sentence social media post.
  • Result: One prompt, complete draft + publishing materials.

2) Frontend Feature Implementation

  • First write a date picker component.
  • Then auto-generate unit tests, list edge cases (timezone/leap year), with complexity and refactoring suggestions.
  • Result: Code + tests + review feedback all-in-one.

3) PRD to Task Breakdown

  • First output complete PRD.
  • Then produce deliverables list, milestones, risks & responses, acceptance criteria.
  • Result: PRD becomes plan, team can start immediately.

Precautions (Pitfall Checklist)

Section titled ‚ÄúPrecautions (Pitfall Checklist)‚Äù
  • Prevent ‚Äúsandbagging‚Äù: Sometimes the model deliberately writes the first version poorly to ‚Äúsignificantly improve‚Äù in step two. Key point: Set hard metrics (length, format, constraints) in step one, and require ‚Äúboth versions must be directly usable‚Äù.
  • Important tasks suggest true two-step: Split into two messages for more stability, especially for compliance, contracts, risk control scenarios; this aligns with multi-round iteration experience in self-refine research.
  • Role switching: Clearly state in step two ‚Äúyou are editor/reviewer/QA‚Äù and provide standards.
  • Control length & format: Provide word limits/table fields to avoid going off-topic.
  • Observability: Require ‚Äúpoint out what changed‚Äù for easy review and comparison.
  • Don‚Äôt rely entirely on it: Content involving timeliness/facts still needs your external verification.

Advanced: Turn ‚ÄúTwo-Step Method‚Äù into Team ‚ÄúButtons‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúAdvanced: Turn ‚ÄúTwo-Step Method‚Äù into Team ‚ÄúButtons‚Äù‚Äù
  • Make into Snippets/Slash commands: /two-step-content, /two-step-code, /two-step-prd.
  • Preset styles & restrictions: Add ‚ÄúDisallowed/Allowed‚Äù blocks in prompts for consistent stable output.
  • Bind with review SOP: Make ‚Äústep two‚Äù always output key points + improvements + actionable checklist.

Summary

Section titled ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù

The essence of Two-Stepping is packaging ‚Äúdoing the work‚Äù and ‚Äúdoing the review‚Äù into delivery. It balances speed and quality, suitable for content, product, development, analysis, and all ‚Äúproduce first, process later‚Äù workflows. One prompt, double harvest.

item.title: Station: Unified Management for Claude/Cursor Agents

Want a self‚Äëhosted, versionable, packable agent runtime so the ‚Äúmini‚Äëagents‚Äù you build in Claude Code or Cursor can actually go live? Station was built exactly for that.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

The tool called Station has been making the rounds lately. It‚Äôs not yet another ‚Äúapplication‚Äëlevel‚Äù agent platform. Instead, it‚Äôs a lightweight runtime and packaging/distribution system purpose‚Äëbuilt for deployable sub‚Äëagents. In one sentence: take the ‚Äúsmall but capable agents‚Äù you create in Claude Code or Cursor, then package them, ship to production, connect permissions, audit every run, and manage versions cleanly.

Highlights at a Glance (Built for Internal Use)

Section titled ‚ÄúHighlights at a Glance (Built for Internal Use)‚Äù

Why Station? Because internal automation isn‚Äôt a normal app: you need secrets, database access, CI/CD, and auditability.

  • Internal‚Äëtask first: Sub‚Äëagents can read production databases (with proper controls), monitor infrastructure, drive CI/CD, run security scans, and handle incident response.
  • Security built‚Äëin: Self‚Äëhosted, secret encryption (AES), multi‚Äëenvironment isolation (dev/staging/prod), and full audit trails.
  • Lightweight and pluggable: A single ~45MB binary with local SQLite out of the box; switch to PostgreSQL in production; natural GitOps (config is versionable).
  • MCP‚Äënative: Acts directly as an MCP runtime, reusing your team‚Äëapproved MCP tools (filesystem, Slack, AWS, K8s, DB, and more).
  • Great DX: A Genkit‚Äëpowered browser playground plus stn develop for visualizing tool calls and execution flows.

What‚Äôs MCP? In short, it‚Äôs a unified protocol for letting LLMs use ‚Äúcontrolled tools.‚Äù Claude Desktop‚Äôs official tutorial includes a quickstart and configuration examples.

How Does Station Work?

The core structure is simple: One .prompt file + a set of MCP tools = a deployable sub‚Äëagent. Environments are organized as dev/staging/prod. Tool definitions live in template.json; environment variables in variables.yml. Finally, everything can be bundled and installed elsewhere.

Station turns those ‚Äúsmall, capable agents‚Äù from ideas discussed at your desktop into deployable, auditable, and replicable internal automation. item.title: Claude Code on a Budget
item.content:encoded:
Trim conversations, pick the right model, lock down permissions ‚Äî and your Claude Code bill can drop by half.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Many teams use Claude Code and feel ‚Äúbudget pain‚Äù every month. It‚Äôs not that you typed too much ‚Äî it‚Äôs the invisible token sink eating the bill. The good news: you can control it, and the effect is immediate.

This guide breaks cost‚Äësaving into three tiers: basic, intermediate, advanced. Follow them and you‚Äôll save the bulk of your spend.

I. Where Does the Money Go? 4 ‚ÄúToken Sinks‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Where Does the Money Go? 4 ‚ÄúToken Sinks‚Äù‚Äù

1) Invisible context from system and memory Claude Code automatically loads the system prompt and layered CLAUDE.md memory (org/project/user). This content enters context on every turn, naturally consuming tokens.**

2) Big price gaps across models Official pricing: Sonnet 4 ‚âà $3/$15 per million input/output tokens; Opus 4/4.1 ‚âà $15/$75. For the same conversation, switching models means ~5√ó unit price.**

3) Context gets fatter as you chat Claude Code supports very large contexts (Sonnet 4 up to 1M tokens in testing). Longer chats trigger auto‚Äëcompression and repeated ‚Äúsetup‚Äù, making tokens fly.**

4) Background and noise spending Beyond visible replies, /cost queries, auto‚Äësummaries, Haiku prompts, etc., also burn small amounts of tokens. Pennies add up.**

Summary: It‚Äôs not that you ask too much ‚Äî it‚Äôs that ‚Äúeverything gets hauled on stage every time.‚Äù

II. Three Tiers of Savings (Use Now)

Section titled ‚ÄúII. Three Tiers of Savings (Use Now)‚Äù

A. Basics: 4 Moves Everyone Should Use

Section titled ‚ÄúA. Basics: 4 Moves Everyone Should Use‚Äù

  • Manual slimming beats passive compression Use /compact proactively, and add a focus directive:

    Auto‚Äëcompression triggers near 95% capacity ‚Äî waiting is too late.**

  • One task per thread; clear when done Start a new session for each small task; once finished, run /clear to avoid a ballooning history.**

  • Pick the right default model Use Sonnet 4 for day‚Äëto‚Äëday development. When you truly hit ‚Äúhard/long/deep reasoning,‚Äù switch to Opus via /model. You can also use ‚ÄúOpus for planning + Sonnet for execution‚Äù ‚Äî stronger planning, cheaper execution.**

  • Check the bill anytime In any session, run /cost to see current spend; teams can check history in the console and set workspace spend limits.**

Figure idea (illustration 2:1 | English copy) ‚ÄúA developer squeezing a giant chat bubble into a slim pill, while a tiny receipt shows shrinking token numbers.‚Äù

B. Intermediate: Tighten the Flow, Shrink the Bill

Section titled ‚ÄúB. Intermediate: Tighten the Flow, Shrink the Bill‚Äù

  • Docs‚Äëfirst to prevent context blowups First have Claude produce a ‚ÄúTODO list / brief plan,‚Äù confirm, then execute. Iterate in Plan Mode (planning mode); confirm and switch back to execution.**

  • Put ‚Äúlong‚Äëterm memory‚Äù into CLAUDE.md Put standards, common commands, and project conventions into CLAUDE.md; next time it applies automatically. Use /memory to edit quickly in a chat when needed. Memory loads by layer automatically, reducing the tokens you spend ‚Äúrepeating yourself.‚Äù**

  • Small commits, easy to roll back Ask Claude to produce a commit message after each small chunk. If something goes wrong, roll back ‚Äî fewer wrong turns means fewer tokens. (Engineering practice)

  • Team rate‚Äëlimits & flight instruments Set sane TPM (tokens per minute) based on org size to avoid costly concurrency ‚Äúmeltdowns.‚Äù**

C. Advanced: Hard‚ÄëCore Cost Downs (Biggest Gains)

Section titled ‚ÄúC. Advanced: Hard‚ÄëCore Cost Downs (Biggest Gains)‚Äù

1) Permission allow/deny lists to stop ‚Äúrandom file reads‚Äù Use /permissions + .claude/settings.json to forbid logs, binaries, and huge directories, and allow only necessary paths. Rules support gitignore patterns.**

Note: plan mode analyzes without changing files; read/write rules shrink the file surface ‚Äî less scanning = fewer tokens.**

2) Be precise to ‚Äúlines,‚Äù not whole files Don‚Äôt paste entire blocks. Provide file path + target line ranges + 5 key bullets to minimize irrelevant scanning. (Engineering practice)

3) Model split: let Opus handle only the ‚Äúexpensive parts‚Äù In /model, use Opus for plans/architecture/cross‚Äëmodule dependency analysis; hand off code generation and fixes to Sonnet. This is the recommended direction from official guidance.**

4) (Team/Gateway) Use Prompt Caching For API or enterprise gateways, prompt caching saves visibly on repeated large prefixes. Official pricing offers cheaper write/hit rates for cached prompts.**

III. Ready‚Äëto‚ÄëUse Cost‚ÄëSaving Checklist

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Ready‚Äëto‚ÄëUse Cost‚ÄëSaving Checklist‚Äù
  • Default to Sonnet; switch to Opus only when needed: flip with /model.**
  • Keep Plan Mode on by default: plan first, execute after confirmation.**
  • Start every session by slimming: /compact Focus on code diffs and test failures.**
  • Close the loop with /clear: prevent ever‚Äëgrowing history.**
  • Strict permissions: use /permissions and readRules/editRules to restrict directories and types.**
  • Audit anytime: /cost + console ‚Äúworkspace spend limit.‚Äù**
  • Write memory into CLAUDE.md: reduce repeated priming and context stuffing.**

IV. Real Savings: Why These Work

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Real Savings: Why These Work‚Äù
  • Unit price spread: Opus costs about 5√ó Sonnet. Concentrate ‚Äúexpensive thinking‚Äù in planning; use Sonnet for execution ‚Äî total cost drops significantly.**
  • Size costs: auto‚Äëloaded memory + long threads fatten context; proactive /compact and /clear shrink transfer volume directly.**
  • Less irrelevant I/O: permissions and rules act as a cost firewall, blocking large, low‚Äëvalue dirs/files.**
  • Background overhead under control: knowing what ‚Äúquietly spends‚Äù helps you avoid pointless refreshes and queries.**

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Claude Code‚Äôs power comes from ‚Äúbringing everything along.‚Äù The key to saving is to bring only what‚Äôs necessary.

Apply this checklist to your project today: start with /model, /compact, /clear, then add CLAUDE.md and permission rules. By month‚Äôs end, your bill should surprise you ‚Äî in a good way.

What do you think? What other money pits have you hit? Share in the comments.
